title: Inheritance of Zelophehad's Daughters
shortSummary: Numbers 36 addresses the concern of the families of Gilead regarding the inheritance rights of Zelophehad's daughters and the preservation of tribal land boundaries. The chapter clarifies God's command that these daughters must marry within their own tribe to keep the inheritance within the tribe of their father, ensuring the tribal allotments remain intact.
timeline: c. 1445 BC - Wilderness Wanderings, just before entering the Promised Land

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: The leader and prophet of Israel who receives and communicates God's commands to the people.

keyCharacters.name: Zelophehad's Daughters (Mahlah, Tirzah, Hoglah, Milcah, Noah)
keyCharacters.description: The five daughters who inherited their father's land because he had no sons, central to the inheritance issue addressed in this chapter.

keyCharacters.name: Chief Fathers of Gilead
keyCharacters.description: Leaders of the families of the tribe of Manasseh who brought the concern about inheritance and tribal land to Moses.

definitions.definition: The land or property passed down from father to children, especially significant in Israel as tribal land allotments.
A special year occurring every 50 years when land was returned to original tribal owners and debts forgiven, preserving tribal boundaries.
A large family group descended from one of the twelve sons of Jacob, each allocated specific land in Canaan.
The leading elders or heads of families within a tribe who held authority and represented their people.

outline.heading: The Concern of the Gilead Families
outline.description: The leaders of the tribe of Manasseh express concern that if Zelophehad’s daughters marry outside their tribe, their inherited land will transfer to another tribe, disrupting tribal boundaries and inheritance.

outline.heading: God’s Command Through Moses
outline.description: Moses relays God’s instruction that the daughters may marry whom they choose, but only within their own tribe, to ensure that tribal inheritance remains within the original family line.

outline.heading: The Daughters’ Obedience
outline.description: The daughters of Zelophehad comply with the command by marrying their cousins within the tribe of Manasseh, thereby preserving their inheritance within their father’s tribe.

outline.heading: Summary of the Commandments
outline.description: The chapter concludes by affirming these instructions as the judgments given by the LORD through Moses to the Israelites on the plains of Moab.

application: Trust in God's wisdom and commands regarding inheritance and family responsibilities, recognizing His care for order and justice.
Obey God’s instructions fully, as the daughters of Zelophehad did, demonstrating faithfulness and respect for divine authority.
Value the importance of preserving family and spiritual heritage, ensuring that blessings and responsibilities are passed on rightly.
Seek to resolve concerns and conflicts through prayerful consultation with godly leadership and Scripture.

keyVerses.text: This is the thing which the LORD doth command concerning the daughters of Zelophehad, saying, Let them marry to whom they think best; only to the family of the tribe of their father shall they marry.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals God's provision for inheritance rights while maintaining tribal integrity, balancing mercy with order.

keyVerses.text: So shall not the inheritance of the children of Israel remove from tribe to tribe: for every one of the children of Israel shall keep himself to the inheritance of the tribe of his fathers.
keyVerses.significance: It emphasizes the importance of preserving tribal boundaries and inheritance as ordained by God.

keyVerses.text: Even as the LORD commanded Moses, so did the daughters of Zelophehad:
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the obedience of the daughters, setting an example of submission to God's word.
